title: Collectible Cars Offer Lots of Opportunity
text:
Text size

The collectible-car market has seen a minor price correction recently, ending a run of crazy money that was paid for such cars as early Porsche 911s, Mercedes-Benz 190SLs, and Toyota 2000s—though all are still quite sought after. It’s understandable that some current or would-be collectors are holding back, waiting to see how values will develop. To help them sort out the present market realities, Penta spoke with experts at three leading classic-car auction houses.

Senior specialist in classic cars at Bonhams

BMW M1: “Just 453 of them were made, styled by Italdesign’s Giorgetto Giugiaro and with a race-tuned chassis and the hottest motor out of BMW,” Minoff says. The M1 was built between 1978 and 1981, and doesn’t come up for sale very often. In 2015, a pristine 1980 M1, resplendent in orange, was sold by Bonhams for $530,396 in Belgium. Minoff also likes the lightweight BMW 3.0 CSL coupe, introduced in 1972. “They’re not quite blue chip, but they’re great cars to tour in,” he says.

Mercedes-Benz SL65 AMG Black Series: “There were very few made, just 375,” Minoff says. “There were substantial changes made to the bodywork, with a lot of carbon fiber used. The market favors them over regular SL65s. Cars don’t have to be old to be valuable.” An example from 2009 (the first year of production) sold for $189,750 by Bonhams at the Greenwich Concours d’Elegance in 2017. The cars were $300,000 new, so some depreciation has occurred.

Saab 900 Turbo: “These are just quirky enough, and there aren’t that many good ones still out there,” Minoff says. “Cars from that era, the 1980s, are hot right now. Buyers who were kids in that period can now afford to buy the car they had on their bedroom wall back then. These early turbo cars have good performance and fit that demographic.” The pre–General Motors Saab 900 Turbo—in coupe, convertible (after 1986), and four-door—was introduced in 1979. It sold in that C900 form until 1994, with a facelift in 1987. A 1993 Saab 900 Turbo convertible with a five-speed transmission sold for $12,750 at BringATrailer.com in April 2019.

A 1967 Ford Bronco 4x4 SUV. Photograph by Jason Rogers

Gord Duff

Global head of auctions at RM Sotheby’s

Hot Commodities 453 Number of BMW M1s that were made. $7.5M Amount paid for a Ferrari F2001 driven by Michael Schumacher. 381 Horsepower in the Porsche 911 Turbo S. $412,500 Sale price of a 1947 Buick Super 8 Custom convertible. 30% Percentage of Ford Broncos sold at auction to Gen Xers.

Formula 1 cars: “They have an exciting future in terms of values,” Duff says. “Specifically, best-of-category cars associated with top drivers, teams, and accolades. Given the global appeal of the F1 sport, with more than 500 million fans watching worldwide, even buyers outside the car-collecting hobby have taken an interest.” An example is RM Sotheby’s sale of the Michael Schumacher championship–winning Ferrari F2001 for a record $7,504,000 at Sotheby’s Contemporary Art Evening Sale in 2017. It was the most ever paid for a modern Formula 1 car at auction. “Bidders outside the car world are interested in F1 cars as art and as alternative investments, further expanding the market,” Duff says.

Porsche 959: “These are good buys right now,” Duff says. “Their values are relatively flat at the moment, and have strong potential as mid- to long-term investments. There were fewer than 350 built and they offer great value compared with their contemporaries: iconic looks, crazy performance, and nowhere to go but up, in my opinion.” The Porsche 959 was manufactured from 1986 to 1993, first as a rally car then as a road car, and was the fastest production vehicle in the world at the time. A 1987 Porsche 959 Komfort sold for $1,150,000 at an RM Sotheby’s sale in Arizona in 2018.

Ferrari SA 599 Aperta: “This Ferrari is in a slightly lower value segment of the market,” Duff says. “As a modern, high-performance Ferrari with a slightly softer appearance and more comfortable driving, the 599 Aperta has wide appeal. Add in the fact that just 80 were built worldwide, and there is certain to be room to grow.” The SA Aperta, the roadster version of the 599, was introduced in 2010. It can go from zero to 62 miles per hour in 3.6 seconds, to 202 mph. The model honored the 80th anniversary of the coach builder Pininfarina. A 2011 Ferrari SA 599 Aperta sold for 933,125 euros (US$1.03 million) in Paris at an RM Sotheby’s auction in February.

A 1947 Buick Super 8 Custom convertible. Photograph by Lucas Scarfone

Craig Jackson

Chairman and CEO at Barrett-Jackson Auction Company

Restomods [restored and modified]: “These are instant collector cars, and there’s a lot of growth in the market as baby boomer buyers have been eclipsed by Gen Xers and Millennials,” Jackson says. “Younger collectors are acquiring discretionary money, and they like the idea of cars that look old but have modern drivetrains.” Barrett-Jackson sold a 1947 Buick Super 8 Custom convertible that looked mostly original—but with a brand-new 580-horsepower engine and automatic transmission, plus brakes with quick-response stopping power and many other options not available in 1947—for $412,500 in Palm Beach, Fla., earlier this year.

Porsche 911 Turbo S: “We’ve seen a spike in these cars, especially with six-speed transmissions,” Jackson says. “People really love them. We’re seeing prices in the low hundreds for the Turbo S, depending on mileage. You want to see the maintenance history, because if they’re neglected it can get very expensive.” The 381-horsepower 911 Turbo S, turned into a lightweight through the removal of such creature comforts as electric windows, power steering, and air conditioning, debuted in 1992, weighing just 2,822 pounds. In 1998, the Turbo S—restricted to just 199 cars—upped the ante with 430 horsepower. The horsepower race continued, but the cars are still relative bargains: A 2004 Porsche Turbo S convertible sold for $35,200 at a Barrett-Jackson auction in Connecticut in 2017.

Ford Bronco: “SUVs are strong across the board,” Jackson says. “A first-generation Bronco, built between 1966 and 1977, was worth $36,000 in 2014; now it’s more than $60,000. They sell well in stock form, and also as restomods. More than 30% of them go to Gen Xers.” To illustrate the strength of the new SUV market, Jackson points to a beautiful, highly customized and Corvette-powered black 1971 K5 Blazer that sold for $220,000 at his Palm Beach auction in 2017. “There were two bidders, both wanting a pristine example of their first car,” Jackson says. “It was perfectly restored, and the buyers appreciated the workmanship. We said we couldn’t guarantee that it would go over $100,000, but it blew past that immediately.”
description: In a slower market, these models still have value
